questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a high fever, weight loss, and a localized abscess on his leg. He has recently returned from a trip to Southeast Asia. Ultrasound of the leg reveals a complex abscess with possible involvement of the underlying bone. A sample of the abscess fluid is sent for culture. Which organism is most commonly associated with abscess formation in this clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkholderia pseudomallei

 

Option B:

 

Burkholderia pseudomallei is the causative agent of melioidosis, which is endemic in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. It is a gram-negative bacillus found in soil and water and can infect humans through inoculation from a contaminated source. Melioidosis often presents with abscess formation and can involve multiple organs, including the skin and bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Burkholderia mallei: Causes glanders, which is primarily a disease of animals such as horses, and human infections are rare.

 

Option C. Burkholderia cepacia: Mainly associated with respiratory infections in patients with cystic fibrosis, not typically known for causing abscesses in travelers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia pseudomallei as the causative organism of melioidosis, commonly presenting with abscesses and commonly contracted in Southeast Asia.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p342, 2/e p355, Ananthanarayan 9/e p317, 18, 10/e p323-324

choices.text: Every strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae produces the diphtheria toxin.
The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron.
The gene for diphtheria toxin production is plasmid-borne.
The diphtheria toxin inhibits cyclic AMP (cAMP) production.

questions.text: A microbiology resident is lecturing on Corynebacterium diphtheriae. She asks the residents which of the following statements regarding the bacterium and its toxin is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron.

 

Option B:

 

The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron. The bacterium produces the toxin when iron levels are low, which is a regulatory mechanism to conserve iron for the bacterium's own use.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Not all strains produce the toxin; only those infected with a bacteriophage that carries the tox gene can produce the diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C: The diphtheria toxin gene (tox) is not plasmid-borne; it is carried by a lysogenic bacteriophage integrated into the bacterium's genome.

 

Option D: The diphtheria toxin does not inhibit cAMP production; it inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria Toxin (DT) - DT consists of two fragments: Fragment A (active unit) and B (binding unit). Fragment B binds to host cell receptors, facilitating entry of Fragment A. Fragment A is internalized into host cells, where it ADP ribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF2). Inhibition of EF2 leads to irreversible inhibition of protein synthesis, resulting in cell death. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p244, 2/e p254, Ananthanarayan 10/e p240

choices.text: Growth in MacConkey and blood agar but not chocolate agar
Growth in MacConkey and chocolate agar but not blood agar
Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium
Growth in MacConkey, blood, and chocolate agar

questions.text: True regarding H. influenzae growth:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium

 

Option C:

 

Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium: Correct. H. influenzae grows on chocolate agar, which provides the X and V factors released from lysed blood cells. It can also grow on blood agar if Staphylococcus species are present (satellitism), which provide the necessary V factor. It does not grow on MacConkey agar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Growth in MacConkey and blood agar but not chocolate agar: H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar as it is a selective medium designed for Gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae has specific growth requirements not met by this medium.

 

Option B. Growth in MacConkey and chocolate agar but not blood agar: Similar to option A, H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar. It can grow on chocolate agar because it provides the necessary factors (X factor - hemin and V factor - NAD) released from lysed blood cells.

 

Option D. Growth in MacConkey, blood, and chocolate agar: As previously explained, H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Haemophilus influenzae grows on chocolate agar and can grow on blood agar under specific conditions (presence of Staphylococcus species for V factor), but it does not grow on MacConkey agar due to its selective nature against non-coliform bacteria.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 2/e p361

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the clinic with a two-day history of fever and severe pain in his right leg. He reports a recent trip to a coastal region where he consumed raw oysters. On examination, his right leg is erythematous with a rapidly progressing edema and hemorrhagic bullae. Which of the following organisms, known for requiring high salt concentrations for growth, is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibrio vulnificus.

 

Option C:

 

This patient's symptoms are indicative of Vibrio vulnificus infection, which is often contracted through the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, particularly oysters, or when an open wound is exposed to sea water. Vibrio vulnificus is a halophilic, or salt-loving, bacterium that thrives in marine environments. Patients with chronic liver disease are particularly at risk for severe disease, which can progress rapidly and be potentially life-threatening, manifesting as wound infections, septicemia, and severe cellulitis with bullous lesions, as seen in this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vibrio cholerae is incorrect because while it is associated with seafood, it typically causes profuse watery diarrhea known as rice-water stools and is not known for causing wound infections or bullae.

 

Option B. Vibrio parahaemolyticus is incorrect because it usually causes gastroenteritis with watery diarrhea following the consumption of undercooked or raw seafood. It is less commonly associated with wound infections compared to Vibrio vulnificus.

 

Option D. Vibrio alginolyticus is incorrect because it is more commonly associated with ear infections and less virulent than Vibrio vulnificus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio vulnificus is a halophilic bacterium found in marine environments, known for causing severe illnesses, especially in individuals with liver conditions. Infections can lead to wound infections, septicemia, and distinctive cellulitis with bullous lesions. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e 341

choices.text: Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset of watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps. She reports eating sushi at a beach resort approximately 24 hours prior to symptom onset. No fever or bloody stools are noted. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

 

Option A:

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a common cause of gastroenteritis following the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, particularly shellfish. The onset of symptoms typically occurs within 24 hours of ingestion and includes watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, nausea, and vomiting. Fever and bloody diarrhea are less common, helping to distinguish this illness from other bacterial causes of gastroenteritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi causes typhoid fever, which is associated with a longer incubation period and systemic symptoms like fever and rose spots.

 

Option C. Shigella sonnei typically presents with bloody diarrhea and fever, which are not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Campylobacter jejuni is more commonly associated with poultry consumption and usually presents with fever and bloody stools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus as the causative agent of gastroenteritis following the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, presenting with watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps without fever or bloody stools.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p337, 2/e p350

questions.text: A 16-year-old male with cystic fibrosis presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. Over the past few months, he has had an increased cough with purulent sputum production and a decline in pulmonary function tests. A sputum culture is most likely to grow which of the following Gram-negative organisms that commonly infects patients with cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Option D:

 

Patients with cystic fibrosis often develop chronic lung infections due to their impaired mucociliary clearance. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common Gram-negative organism responsible for chronic pulmonary infections in these patients, particularly by the time they reach adolescence. It can lead to a progressive decline in lung function and is notorious for its resistance to many antibiotics and ability to form biofilms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Escherichia coli is a common Gram-negative bacterium but is not the most common cause of lung infections in cystic fibrosis patients.

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause community-acquired pneumonia, especially in alcoholics and diabetics, but it is not typically associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option C. Legionella pneumophila causes Legionnaires' disease, which is characterized by severe pneumonia but is not commonly associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa as the most common Gram-negative organism causing chronic lung infections in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p340, 2/e p353

choices.text: Mutations in the proteins on the bacterial surface
Changes in the membrane permeability to penicillin
Production of an alternative penicillin binding protein

questions.text: A clinical microbiologist is discussing the mechanisms of antibiotic resistance with a group of medical students. She explains that different bacteria have developed various strategies to survive in the presence of antibiotics. What is the primary mechanism by which Streptococcus pneumoniae develops resistance to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Production of an alternative penicillin binding protein

 

Option D:

 

Resistance to penicillin in Streptococcus pneumoniae is most commonly due to the alteration of penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), which reduce the affinity of the antibiotic for its target.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Production of Beta lactamase is a common resistance mechanism in other bacteria but not the primary one in Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option B: Mutations in the proteins on the bacterial surface can contribute to resistance but are not the primary mechanism for penicillin resistance in S. pneumoniae.

 

Option C: Changes in membrane permeability are a less common mechanism of resistance for S. pneumoniae when compared to PBP alterations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of penicillin resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae is due to the production of altered penicillin-binding proteins, leading to a decreased affinity for the drug.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology1/e p234, 2/e p242

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic with a non-healing ulcer on his foot. The ulcer has a greenish discharge, and cultures reveal the presence of Burkholderia cepacia. The patient has a history of multiple antibiotic allergies and requires monotherapy. Which antibiotic should be avoided due to intrinsic resistance by B. cepacia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polymyxin B

 

Option C:

 

Burkholderia cepacia complex is intrinsically resistant to polymyxin B. This resistance is due to the unique structure of the lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane of B. cepacia, which reduces the binding affinity of polymyxins. In the clinical context, it is crucial to avoid using polymyxin B when treating infections with this organism, especially in a monotherapy scenario where the selection of an effective antibiotic is critical.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin: Although resistance can occur, B. cepacia is not intrinsically resistant to ciprofloxacin, and it can be used in certain cases.

 

Option B. Ceftazidime: B. cepacia may be susceptible to ceftazidime, although resistance can vary among strains.

 

Option D. Meropenem: This antibiotic is typically active against B. cepacia, and it could be used unless the specific strain is known to be resistant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia cepacia is intrinsically resistant to polymyxin B, which has implications for antibiotic selection in infected patients.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1e/p342, 2/e p355-356

questions.text: During an examination of a veterinary worker who presents with a fever and has been exposed to equine animals, he mentions a recent outbreak of a zoonotic infection at the stable where he works. Which of the following statements regarding the pathogen is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It causes glanders disease. 

 

Option A:

 

Burkholderia mallei is the causative agent of glanders, which is a contagious and potentially fatal zoonotic infection that primarily affects horses, donkeys, and mules. Humans can be infected through direct contact with infected animals or their tissues and fluids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Burkholderia mallei is not motile, which distinguishes it from Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis.

 

Option D. It does not cause melioidosis; this is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, which is a separate but related organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia mallei as the causative agent of glanders, a zoonotic infection that affects horses and can be transmitted to humans.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p342-43, 2/e p356, Ananthanarayan 9/e p317, 10/e p323

choices.text: Also called as Pfeiffer’s bacilli
In acute infections, capsulated strains are often isolated

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with symptoms of high fever, difficulty in breathing, and a barking cough. On examination, the child appears distressed and has a hoarse voice. A throat swab is taken and sent for bacterial culture and sensitivity. The laboratory report identifies the presence of a specific bacterium known to cause respiratory tract infections in children. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, the pediatrician suspects an infection with Haemophilus influenzae. Which of the following statements is true about Haemophilus influenzae?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Also called as Pfeiffer’s bacilli

 

Option A:

 

Haemophilus influenzae, first described by Richard Pfeiffer during an influenza pandemic, is known as Pfeiffer's bacillus. It is a significant cause of respiratory tract infections in children. Despite its historical association with influenza, subsequent research revealed that the influenza virus, not H. influenzae, causes influenza.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. In acute infections, encapsulated strains are often isolated: The capsulated strains of H. influenzae, especially type b (Hib), are more often associated with serious invasive infections like meningitis, pneumonia, and epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Gram-negative motile bacilli: H. influenzae is a small, pleomorphic, Gram-negative bacillus, but it is non-motile.

 

Option D. Easily cultured: H. influenzae requires specific growth conditions (chocolate agar with X and V factors), so it's not "easily" cultured in a general sense, but it can be reliably cultured under appropriate laboratory conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haemophilus influenzae, also known as Pfeiffer's bacillus, is a significant cause of respiratory infections in children but is not the cause of influenza. Encapsulated strains, particularly type b, are associated with serious infections, but the bacterium is non-motile and requires specific growth conditions, like chocolate agar with X and V factors. It is Voges-Proskauer (VP) test negative, a detail relevant in differentiating it from Enterobacteriaceae members.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p345, 2/e p359, Ananthanarayan 9/e p327, 10/e p333

questions.text: During a review of hospital-acquired infections, a case is presented of a 65-year-old man who developed diarrhea after a two-week course of antibiotics for pneumonia. What is the most significant risk factor for the development of his Clostridium difficile infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prolonged antibiotic therapy. 

 

Option A:

 

Antibiotic use, particularly prolonged use, is the most significant risk factor for Clostridium difficile infection due to disruption of normal gut flora.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While proton pump inhibitors are associated with a slightly increased risk of C. difficile infection, they are not as significant a risk factor as antibiotic use.

 

Option C: Use of rectal thermometers has not been established as a risk factor for C. difficile infection.

 

Option D: Although a longer hospital stay may be associated with a higher risk of acquiring C. difficile, it is the antibiotic use during the stay that is the direct risk factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prolonged antibiotic therapy as a significant risk factor for the development of Clostridium difficile infection due to disruption of normal gut flora

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p265,2/e p275 Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e

questions.text: During a public health lecture on vaccine-preventable diseases, the topic of Neisseria meningitidis vaccination is discussed. The current vaccines provide coverage against several serogroups of this pathogen. Which serogroup of Neisseria meningitidis is NOT covered by the meningococcal conjugate vaccines (MCV-4 and MPSV-4)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Option B:

 

The meningococcal conjugate vaccines (MCV-4 and MPSV-4) provide protection against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135. They do not provide protection against serogroup B, which requires a different vaccine formulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The meningococcal conjugate vaccines (MCV-4 and MPSV-4) provide protection against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135.  not against serogroup B.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e, p248

questions.text: A microbiology lab technician is analyzing bacterial samples from a patient with a suspected Staphylococcus aureus infection. The patient's infection has not responded to treatment with semisynthetic penicillins. The technician is asked to identify the gene most commonly associated with resistance to these antibiotics in S. aureus. Which gene should be suspected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Meca Gene

 

Option C:

 

The Meca gene is responsible for methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus by encoding an altered penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) with a low affinity for β-lactam antibiotics, including semisynthetic penicillins. The presence of this gene indicates that the S. aureus is likely methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA), which requires alternative treatment options.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The Blaz gene encodes β-lactamase, which can confer resistance to penicillins, but it is not specifically associated with resistance to semisynthetic penicillins in S. aureus.

 

Option B: The Vana gene is associated with vancomycin resistance, typically in Enterococci, not S. aureus.

 

Option D: The Tetm gene is related to tetracycline resistance and is not involved in resistance to semisynthetic penicillins.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A laboratory scientist is presented with two bacterial isolates from a skin infection. Both are gram-positive cocci, but it is critical to determine whether the isolates are Staphylococcus spp. or Micrococcus spp. to guide treatment effectively. Which test would best differentiate between these two genera?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Modified Oxidase test

 

Option B:

 

While both Micrococcus and Staphylococcus are catalase-positive, they can be differentiated by the Modified oxidase test. Micrococcus species are modified oxidase-positive, meaning they produce a cytochrome oxidase enzyme that can be detected by the test, while Staphylococcus species are typically modified oxidase-negative. 

 

Gram staining is not useful for differentiation in this case because both genera are gram-positive. The coagulase test is also not the best choice for differentiation since it is used primarily to distinguish between Staphylococcus aureus (coagulase-positive) and other Staphylococcus species (coagulase-negative).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The catalase test can differentiate staphylococci (catalase-positive) from streptococci (catalase-negative), but both Micrococcus and Staphylococcus are catalase-positive.

 

Option C: Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties; however, both Micrococcus and Staphylococcus are gram-positive cocci, so this test would not distinguish between them.

 

Option D: The coagulase test is used to differentiate Staphylococcus aureus (which is coagulase-positive) from other Staphylococcus species, but not from Micrococcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modified oxidase test is the most effective method for distinguishing between the genera Micrococcus and Staphylococcus, with Micrococcus being modified oxidase-positive and Staphylococcus being oxidase-negative. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p211

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of valve replacement surgery presents with a new heart murmur and fever 12 months post-operation. His blood cultures are positive, suggesting infective endocarditis. Which organism is most commonly associated with late-onset prosthetic valve endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Streptococcus viridans

 

Explanation:  

 

Streptococcus viridans is identified as the most commonly associated organism with late-onset prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE). This group of bacteria is part of the normal oral and respiratory flora and is known for causing subacute endocarditis, particularly in individuals with predisposing heart conditions or prosthetic heart valves. The late-onset nature of the infection suggests a more indolent course, which aligns with the pathogenic behavior of S. viridans, allowing it to adhere to and colonize prosthetic materials over time. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: While S. aureus is a common cause of native valve endocarditis and can be associated with early-onset PVE (occurring within 12 months of surgery), it is less commonly associated with late-onset PVE compared to coagulase-negative staphylococci like S. epidermidis.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus epidermidis: S. epidermidis is a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus species frequently linked to early -onset PVE due to its ability to form biofilms on prosthetic devices. 

 

Option D. HACEK group bacteria: The HACEK group are commonly associated with endocarditis but less associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus viridans is the most commonly associated organism with late-onset prosthetic valve endocarditis, particularly due to its ability to cause subacute infections in individuals with prosthetic heart valves.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a painful ulcer on his lower leg. He recalls falling at school a week ago. On examination, the ulcer is 3 cm in diameter with raised erythematous borders. A swab culture of the lesion grows beta-hemolytic streptococci. Concurrently, an outbreak of pharyngitis at his school was found to be caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci as well. Molecular typing is considered to determine if the strains from the ulcer and the pharyngitis outbreak are related. Which of the following molecular markers is most useful for distinguishing different strains of beta-hemolytic streptococci?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) M protein

 

Option B:

 

M protein is a virulence factor of Streptococcus pyogenes, the most common beta-hemolytic streptococcus, and it is highly variable among different strains. It is used in typing strains because its antigenic variability allows for differentiation between them. This is important in epidemiological studies, such as tracking the spread of infection in outbreaks.

 

The question tells about 2 strains affecting the patient , one causing an ulcer on leg and another causing pharyngitis. Streptococcus pyogenes is known to cause both the disease but the strains of Streptococcus pyogenes causing these 2 infections could be same or different. To know about this the best test to do would be M typing. 
C carbohydrate antigen is used to differentiate between serogroup of beta hemolytic streptococci. 
 

Explanation:

 

Option A: C-carbohydrate antigen is a component of the cell wall of all Group A Streptococci and is not variable enough to distinguish between different strains.

 

Option C: Emu protein is not a recognized molecular marker for typing Streptococcus pyogenes.

 

Option D: Mec A gene is associated with methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus, not with streptococci, and therefore would not be helpful in differentiating streptococcal strains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The role of M protein in the molecular typing of Streptococcus pyogenes strains, which can be used to differentiate between strains in epidemiological investigations of infections.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastrys Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/r p227, 2/e p228, Ananthanarayan 9/e p209, 10/e p212

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with fever, malaise, and a painful erythematous lesion on his shin, which he reports developed after falling at the playground. The lesion has a honey-colored crust, and underlying erythema. A Gram stain of the discharge reveals gram-positive cocci in chains, and culture plates demonstrate hemolytic colonies. The physician considers further testing to confirm the specific etiological agent responsible for the skin infection. Which test would be most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacitracin sensitivity test

 

Option C:

 

The clinical picture and laboratory findings suggest a Group A Streptococcus (GAS) skin infection. GAS, or Streptococcus pyogenes, is typically sensitive to bacitracin and can be identified by a bacitracin sensitivity test, where a zone of inhibition around a bacitracin disk would confirm the organism's susceptibility and, thereby, its identity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bile solubility test: This test is used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is bile soluble, from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci.

 

Option B: Optochin sensitivity test: This test is also used to identify Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is optochin-sensitive, from other viridans group streptococci.

 

Option D: Catalase test: This test distinguishes staphylococci (catalase-positive) from streptococci (catalase-negative). Since we already know the organism is a streptococcus, this test would not be useful in further identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bacitracin sensitivity test is key for identifying Group A Streptococcus (GAS) in suspected skin infections, as GAS shows a distinct zone of inhibition to bacitracin. This differentiates it from other bacteria. Other tests like the bile solubility and optochin sensitivity tests are used for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae, distinguishing it from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. The catalase test differentiates staphylococci (catalase-positive) from streptococci (catalase-negative), but it's not helpful for further identification within streptococcal species.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p227, 2/e p234, Ananthanarayan 9/e p215,10/e p217- 218

questions.text: A patient in the intensive care unit (ICU) with a central venous catheter develops a fever after a week of antibiotic therapy with ceftazidime and amikacin. Blood cultures reveal gram-positive cocci in chains, and the organism is catalase-negative. Vancomycin is initiated, but the patient's blood cultures remain positive for the same organism after two weeks of therapy. Which organism is the most likely cause of this persistent bacteremia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Viridans group streptococci

 

Option B:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of BLOOD STREAM INFECTIONS due to central venous catheter, often caused by viridans group streptococci. These organisms are catalase-negative, gram-positive cocci in chains, and can be resistant to vancomycin, especially in the setting of suboptimal dosing or biofilm-associated infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Staphylococcus aureus is usually catalase-positive, coagulase-positive and gram positive cocci in clusters.

 

Option C: Enterococcus faecalis can cause persistent bacteremia but is usually vancomycin-resistant but is gram positive cocci in pairs.

 

Option D: Coagulase-negative staphylococci are also catalase-positive and would not typically present as cocci in chains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viridans group streptococci is a common cause of , bloodstream infections, particularly in patients with icentral venous catheters, and to recognize the challenge of treating biofilm-associated infections that can lead to persistent bacteremia despite appropriate antibiotic therapy.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastrys Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p 231, 2/e p238

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents with fever, a new heart murmur, and petechiae after a recent dental procedure. Blood cultures are drawn, and empiric antibiotic therapy is initiated. The cultures eventually grow gram-positive cocci that are not encapsulated and are alpha-hemolytic. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus viridans

 

Option A:

 

The viridans group of streptococci is a common cause of subacute infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with preexisting cardiac conditions who undergo dental procedures. They are part of the normal flora of the oropharynx, are not encapsulated, and display alpha-hemolysis on blood agar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae, while alpha-hemolytic, is more commonly associated with pneumonia and meningitis rather than endocarditis.

 

Option C: Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) is beta-hemolytic and is not typically associated with endocarditis following dental procedures.

 

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus can cause acute endocarditis, often in intravenous drug users or in patients with prosthetic valves and is usually beta-hemolytic and coagulase-positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus viridans is a common etiological agent for infective endocarditis in patients with preexisting valvular heart disease following dental procedures.

 

MC cause of Native valve endocarditis: S. aureus

 

MC cause of subacute endocarditis: MC agent Streptococcus Viridans

 

MC Streptococcus Viridans causing endocarditis: S. sanguis

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p231, 2/e p238-239, Harrison, 19/e p971,20/e p1088- 1089

It is an etiological agent of pneumonia and otitis media.

questions.text: A medical student is studying the characteristics of various pathogens. Concerning Streptococcus pneumoniae, which of the following statements is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumococcal meningitis is the least virulent of the major bacterial meningitides.

 

Option D:

 

Pneumococcal meningitis, caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, is not considered the least virulent form of bacterial meningitis; in fact, it is associated with significant morbidity and mortality.

 

 

Figure: Pneumococci in gram-stained smear of sputum [lanceolate shaped gram-positive cocci in pair surrounded by clear halo (capsule)]

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Streptococcus pneumoniae is indeed bile-sensitive, which is used to differentiate it from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci.

 

Option B: The capsule of S. pneumoniae is a major virulence factor and facilitates the establishment of infection by preventing phagocytosis.

 

Option C: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a well-known etiological agent of both pneumonia and otitis media.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumococcal meningitis, caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, is one of the more severe forms of bacterial meningitis, with high morbidity and mortality rates, especially in certain age groups. 

 

S. pneumoniae is bile-sensitive, its capsule is a crucial virulence factor allowing for infection establishment, and it is a common etiological agent of pneumonia and otitis media.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p234, 2/e p240-241, Ananthanarayan 9/e p223, 10/e p223-224

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 30 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of fever, muscle aches, and nausea. She reports eating soft cheeses and deli meats in the past week. Blood cultures are drawn and empirically treated for suspected sepsis. The cultures grow a gram-positive rod that demonstrates tumbling motility at room temperature. Which of the following characteristics is incorrect regarding the organism isolated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Considered a gram-negative coccobacillus. 

 

Option C:

 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive rod, not gram-negative, and it is not a coccobacillus. 

 

The clinical scenario provided suggests a foodborne illness with a typical presentation and risk factors for listeriosis. The tumbling motility, enhanced growth at cold temperatures (cold enrichment), and risk of meningitis in neonates are all classic characteristics of Listeria monocytogenes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Exhibits enhanced growth at 4°C (cold enrichment) - This is a true characteristic of Listeria as it can replicate at refrigerator temperatures, which is a unique feature among pathogens.

 

Option B: Typically presents with meningitis in neonates and immunocompromised individuals - This is also true. Listeriosis can cause severe infections such as meningitis, especially in high-risk groups such as neonates, pregnant women, and immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D: Displays tumbling motility when observed under a microscope - This is a true characteristic. The tumbling motility is due to the organism's flagellar movement and is a diagnostic clue in the laboratory identification of Listeria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes, is a food-borne pathogen that poses a significant risk, especially to neonates, pregnant women, and the elderly. Transmitted primarily through contaminated food, vertical transmission (mother to fetus during birth), and is common in aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk, and salads due to its ability to survive refrigeration. 

 

Ampicillin is the drug of choice

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p296, 2/e p308

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to a sudden onset of fever, poor feeding, and irritability. The infant was born at term without complications, but the mother reports that she consumed soft cheese during the third trimester. On examination, the infant is lethargic and has a bulging fontanelle. Lumbar puncture is performed, revealing gram-positive rods in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Which organism is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Listeria monocytogenes. 

 

Option B:

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of meningitis, which in a new-born can be caused by Listeria, especially given the history of the mother's consumption of potentially contaminated food. The presence of gram-positive rods in the CSF is characteristic of Listeria infection in neonates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) - While GBS is a common cause of neonatal meningitis, it is typically a gram-positive coccus, not a rod.

 

Option C: Clostridium tetani - This organism causes tetanus, which does not typically present with CSF infection or seizures in neonates.

 

Option D: Bacillus cereus - This is a rare cause of neonatal meningitis and is usually associated with traumatic or surgical introductions of the organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p296, 2/e p308, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p982-83, 20/e p1100

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 5-day history of severe abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. He reports eating an undercooked hamburger at a local restaurant a week ago. A stool culture grows out Escherichia coli that does not ferment sorbitol. Which E. coli serotype is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) O157:H7.

 

Option A:

 

E. coli O157:H7 is the most commonly identified serotype associated with hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS). This serotype is known to produce Shiga toxin and does not ferment sorbitol, which helps differentiate it from other E. coli serotypes. The history of eating undercooked meat is a risk factor for infection with E. coli O157:H7.

EHEC - 

 

Serotypes associated with EHEC are: O157:H7 (most common serotype). Other serotypes are rarely associated such as O26:Hll, O6, O55, O91, O103, O111 and O113.

 

EHEC is usually transmitted by contaminated food, i.e. consumption of lettuce, spinach, sprouts and undercooked ground beef. The infective dose is very low. Only few organisms ( <102 bacilli) are required to initiate the infection

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. O159:H9 - This serotype is not commonly associated with hemorrhagic colitis or HUS.

 

Option C. O111:H8 - While O111 is a Shiga toxin-producing E. coli, the correct antigen combination is O111:H8, not commonly associated with hemorrhagic colitis compared to O157:H7.

 

Option D. O104:H21 - This serotype is not commonly associated with hemorrhagic colitis or HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli O157:H7 as the serotype most frequently associated with hemorrhagic colitis following consumption of undercooked ground beef.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p304, 2/e p316, Ananthanarayan 9/e p279, 10/e p285

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a firm swelling of the jaw that has been progressively enlarging over several months. He reports a dull ache in the area and occasional drainage of pus from small openings in the skin. Examination reveals a woody-hard, non-tender mass with several draining sinuses on the left side of the jaw. Histopathological examination of the exudate reveals filamentous organisms that are not acid-fast. What is the most accurate statement regarding the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The first-line treatment for the infection caused by this organism is penicillin.

 

Option D:

 

Actinomyces israelii is most commonly associated with cervicofacial actinomycosis and is treated with penicillin. The clinical scenario described is classic for cervicofacial actinomycosis, often referred to as "lumpy jaw."

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It typically presents as a rapidly growing mycetoma on the extremities - This is incorrect. Actinomycosis usually presents with slow-growing masses and is not typical for actinomycetoma, which is caused by a different group of organisms.

 

Option B: It is most commonly associated with thoracic and pulmonary infections - This is incorrect. While Actinomyces can cause thoracic and pulmonary infections, the most common presentation is cervicofacial.

 

Option C: Detection in clinical specimens is best achieved with fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) - This is incorrect. While FISH can be used for detection, it is not the standard or most common method for diagnosing Actinomyces.

choices.text: Trichomonas vaginalis, indicating a protozoan infection
Candida species, suggestive of a yeast infection
Herpes simplex virus Type II, indicative of a viral infection
Actinomyces species, associated with IUD use

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents for her routine gynecological examination. She has an intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception and reports no significant medical history. On examination, her Pap smear reveals small clusters of bacteria associated with squamous cells, without any signs of cellular atypia or viral cytopathic effects.(see figure). There are no protozoans or yeast cells identified. Given this finding, which organism is most likely present on the Pap smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Actinomyces species, associated with IUD use. 

 

Option D:

 

Actinomyces species can be part of the normal flora but are also known to cause infections in the setting of IUD use. Their presence on a Pap smear in a patient with an IUD is indicative of actinomycosis, which does not necessarily warrant the removal of the IUD or treatment unless symptomatic infection is present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Trichomonas vaginalis - This protozoan infection typically shows flagellated protozoans on wet mount and not on a Pap smear.

 

Option B: Candida species - Candida yeast infections are usually identified on Pap smears by the presence of pseudohyphae or budding yeasts.

 

Option C: Herpes simplex virus Type II - Herpes infection is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells and cells with ground-glass nuclei, which are not described in the presented scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of small bacterial clusters associated with squamous cells on a Pap smear in a woman with an IUD is indicative of Actinomyces species. Actinomyces are bacteria that can be associated with long-term IUD use and can lead to actinomycosis, a rare but potentially serious infection. This finding warrants further investigation and possibly the removal of the IUD.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p292-93

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with headaches and confusion. MRI of the brain reveals a ring-enhancing lesion suggestive of an abscess. Biopsy and culture of the lesion show branching, weakly acid-fast, Gram-positive bacilli. Which organism is the most likely cause of the brain abscess in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia species, which are weakly acid-fast and can cause cerebral abscesses, especially in immunocompromised patients.

 

Option A:

 

Nocardia can affect the central nervous system, and the presence of branching, weakly acid-fast, Gram-positive bacilli in a brain abscess is characteristic of nocardiosis.

 

 

Nocardia on acid fast staining

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Actinomyces species - These are typically not acid-fast and are more commonly associated with cervicofacial infections than brain abscesses.

 

Option C: Pseudomonas aeruginosa - While this organism can cause brain abscesses, it is a Gram-negative rod and would not be weakly acid-fast.

 

Option D: Acinetobacter species - These are Gram-negative rods and are not commonly associated with brain abscesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species as a common cause of cerebral abscesses in immunocompromised patients, with diagnostic features including branching, weakly acid-fast, Gram-positive bacilli. 

 

 

Ref: ApurbaSastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p294, 2/e p304-305

choices.text: Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC)
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)
Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC)

questions.text: A research laboratory is investigating an outbreak of gastrointestinal infections in a local community. They have isolated a strain of E. coli that seems to be implicated in the illness. The patients present with fever, abdominal cramping, and bloody diarrhea. The researchers decide to perform a test involving the inoculation of the conjunctiva of a guinea pig to observe for the development of keratoconjunctivitis as part of their pathogenicity testing. Which type of E. coli are they most likely attempting to identify with this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC).

 

Option D:

 

The Sereny test is used to demonstrate the invasiveness of certain bacteria. When it comes to E. coli, Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) causes a syndrome similar to shigellosis, including fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea. EIEC invades and multiplies within the colonic epithelium, causing inflammation and cell death, leading to these symptoms. The Sereny test involves inoculating the conjunctiva of a guinea pig with the bacteria. The development of keratoconjunctivitis within 24-48 hours is considered a positive result, indicating the invasive nature of the strain.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) - This causes watery diarrhea and does not typically involve invasion of the gut mucosa.

 

Option B. Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) - Causes watery diarrhea especially in children, and does not invade cells as EIEC does.

 

Option C. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) - While it can cause bloody diarrhea, it does not invade cells in the same manner as EIEC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sereny test is used to identify Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) by demonstrating its ability to cause keratoconjunctivitis in guinea pigs, indicative of its invasive properties.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p304, 2/e p316, Ananthanarayan10/e p285

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 22 weeks gestation presents to the clinic complaining of fever, flank pain, and dysuria for the past two days. Urinalysis shows pyuria, bacteriuria, and a positive leukocyte esterase test. A urine culture is pending. Based on the clinical presentation, which organism is the most likely cause of her acute pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Escherichia coli.

 

Option A:

 

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of acute pyelonephritis in pregnant women, as it is in the general population. The ascending infection from the lower urinary tract is the typical pathogenesis of pyelonephritis, and E. coli, being a common colonizer of the gastrointestinal tract, is often responsible for these infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae - While Klebsiella can cause urinary tract infections, it is less common than E. coli.

 

Option C. Neisseria gonorrhoeae - This is a sexually transmitted pathogen that can cause urethritis, but it is not typically associated with pyelonephritis.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus - Rarely causes urinary tract infections and is not typically associated with pyelonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Escherichia coli as the most common cause of acute pyelonephritis in pregnant women, which presents with fever, flank pain, and dysuria.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p303, 2/e p314, Harrison’s 18/e chapter 288

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) inquires about dietary modifications that could help prevent future episodes. She has no known drug allergies and is not currently on any prophylactic antibiotics. Which of the following beverages is most likely to reduce the risk of recurrent UTIs in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cranberry juice.

 

Option D:

 

Cranberry juice has been shown to help prevent urinary tract infections (UTIs). It contains proanthocyanidins that can inhibit the adhesion of E. coli bacteria to the urothelial lining of the bladder and urethra, reducing the risk of infection. While cranberry juice is not a substitute for antimicrobial therapy in active infection, it may be a useful adjunct in the prevention of recurrent UTIs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Grape juice - There is no evidence that grape juice has a significant effect on UTI prevention.

 

Option B. Raspberry juice - Like grape juice, there is no evidence to suggest raspberry juice can prevent UTIs.

 

Option C. Orange juice - While a healthy beverage, orange juice has not been shown to prevent UTIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cranberry juice helps to prevent recurrent urinary tract infections due to its ability to inhibit the adhesion of E. coli to the urinary tract lining.

 

Ref: Journal- Inhibitory activity of cranberry extract on the bacterial adhesiveness in the urine of women: An ex-vivo study’. Int. journal of immunopathology and pharmacology, Tempera et al 2010-23 (2): 611–8.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with facial flushing, rash, and palpitations 30 minutes after consuming a fish dish at a local restaurant. He also complains of a peppery taste in his mouth while eating. His vital signs are stable, and he has no significant medical history. Which gram-negative bacteria, often associated with improperly stored fish, is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Morganella species

 

Option D:

 

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of scombroid fish poisoning, which is not an infection but a form of food poisoning that occurs due to the ingestion of fish that has not been properly refrigerated. This allows the growth of certain bacteria, including gram-negative Proteus species, which produce histidine decarboxylase. This enzyme converts histidine in the fish to histamine, leading to symptoms resembling an allergic reaction.

 

The organism morganella morganii , present under the proteae tribe is the one that causes Scromboid fish poisoning. 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: This is a gram-positive bacterium, not gram-negative. It is commonly associated with food poisoning, particularly in foods like dairy products, meat, and sandwiches, but not typically with fish. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which are different from the symptoms presented by the patient.

 

Option B. Shigella species: These are gram-negative bacteria, but they are primarily associated with waterborne outbreaks and not with fish. Shigella typically causes symptoms like diarrhea (often bloody), fever, and stomach cramps, which are not in line with the symptoms described by the patient.

 

Option C. Salmonella species: While these are gram-negative bacteria and can be associated with foodborne illnesses, they are more commonly linked to poultry, eggs, and meat rather than fish. The symptoms of Salmonella infection include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps, different from the symptoms the patient is experiencing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MORGANELLA  species as a gram-negative bacterium that can release histamine when it inhabits improperly stored fish, leading to scombroid poisoning.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p311, 2/e p323

questions.text: A microbiology lab is testing bacterial isolates from a patient with a suspected Shigella infection. One isolate is noted to ferment lactose slowly, with a positive result only after 48 hours of incubation. Which species of Shigella is known to exhibit this late lactose fermenting characteristic?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S. sonnei.

 

Option A:

 

S. sonnei is known for its ability to ferment lactose, but unlike typical lactose-fermenting bacteria that do so within 24 hours, it ferments lactose slowly and may only show a positive result after 48 hours, which is termed "late lactose fermentation."

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. S. flexneri - This species does not ferment lactose, or it does so very weakly and is not known for late lactose fermentation.

 

Option C. S. boydii - Similar to S. flexneri, it does not typically ferment lactose.

 

Option D. S. dysenteriae - This species is a non-lactose fermenter and is known for more severe disease presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p305, 2/e p317

questions.text: During a lecture on infectious diseases, a professor discusses the epidemiology of typhoid fever. She emphasizes the importance of the infective dose in the transmission of the disease. What is the typical infective dose required for Salmonella typhi to cause typhoid fever in a susceptible individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 102-105 bacilli

 

Option C:

 

The infective dose for Salmonella typhi is relatively low, and ingesting as few as 102-105  organisms can cause typhoid fever in a susceptible individual. This low infective dose is a factor in the spread of typhoid fever, particularly in areas with poor sanitation where small amounts of contaminated food or water can cause infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The infective dose of Salmonella typhi, the causative agent of typhoid fever, ranges from 102-105  organisms.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p319, 2/e p332, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1049-53, 20/e p1174

questions.text: 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with symptoms of gastroenteritis. He reports that he started experiencing abdominal pain, diarrhea, and mild fever after attending a local seafood festival. A stool culture on differential media shows the presence of a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that produces hydrogen sulfide. Which of the following Salmonella species is the patient most likely infected with?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S. Typhimurium.

 

Option A:

 

S. Typhimurium  is a non-typhoidal salmonella and is known to produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which can be detected on differential media such as Hektoen enteric agar where it produces black colonies due to H2S production. This bacterium is a common cause of gastroenteritis and can be contracted from various food sources, making it a likely culprit in a patient with post-food festival gastroenteritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. S. Typhi: While this is a hydrogen sulfide-producing species, it is typically associated with a more systemic illness known as typhoid fever (Enteric fever), rather than gastroenteritis.

 

Option C. S. Paratyphi A and d) S. Paratyphi B: These species also cause enteric fevers similar to S. Typhi and are not commonly associated with the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S. Typhimurium as a hydrogen sulfide-producing Salmonella species commonly associated with gastroenteritis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastrys Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/ep321, 2/e p336

questions.text: A 24-year-old cook at a university dormitory was recently diagnosed with chronic gallbladder carriage of Salmonella Typhi. Which of the following tests is considered the gold standard for diagnosing a chronic carrier state of Salmonella Typhi?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow culture.

 

Option D:

 

Bone marrow culture is considered the gold standard for diagnosing chronic carriers of Salmonella Typhi because it is less affected by prior antibiotic use and has a higher yield than blood cultures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vi agglutination test: This test detects antibodies against the Vi capsule of S. Typhi and is useful for diagnosing typhoid fever, not the carrier state.

 

Option B. Blood culture in Brain Heart Infusion broth: While blood cultures can be positive in acute infection, they are less reliable for carriers.

 

Option C. Widal test: This serological test is not specific or sensitive enough for the diagnosis of the carrier state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bone marrow culture is the gold standard for diagnosing a chronic carrier state of Salmonella Typhi.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p325, 2/e p337, Ananthanarayan 9/e p299, 10/e p305

questions.text: A 32-year-old researcher who specializes in the history of medieval diseases is presenting an academic paper on the epidemiology of the plague. During the Q&A session, a medical student inquiries about current concepts regarding the prevention and treatment of plague. The researcher wants to clarify a point about contemporary management of the disease. Which of the following statements about the plague is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tetracycline is used for both chemoprophylaxis and treatment.

 

Option C:

 

Tetracycline and other antibiotics like doxycycline are indeed used for both the treatment and chemoprophylaxis of plague. This is a critical point in the management of plague exposures and infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Plague can have seasonal patterns, especially in places where the disease is endemic, but this is not the primary epidemiological pattern as it is primarily spread by flea bites or contact with contaminated fluids or tissues.

 

Option B. There was a vaccine for plague, but it is no longer available.

 

Option D. The causative agent of plague, Yersinia pestis, is a gram-negative, non-motile bacterium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetracycline is utilized for both chemoprophylaxis and treatment of plague, which is caused by Yersinia pestis, a non-motile gram-negative bacterium.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing cases of cholera in a recent outbreak. One patient's chart indicates a daily stool output of 1000-1500 ml. This degree of fluid loss in cholera is categorized as:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cholera gravis.

 

Option D:

 

Sudden onset of explosive life-threatening diarrhea is known as cholera gravis, seen in 5% of cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cholera dumdum - Incorrect, as this is not a recognized classification of cholera severity.

 

Option C. Cholera magna - Incorrect, typically refers to severe cholera with stool outputs significantly greater than 1500 ml/day.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cholera gravis, characterized by sudden, explosive, life-threatening diarrhea, occurs in about 5% of cholera cases. Others like Cholera dumdum and Cholera intermedius are not recognized classifications of cholera severity. Cholera magna refers to severe cholera with stool output exceeding 1500 ml/day.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p328, 2/e p344

questions.text: A microbiology lab is comparing two bacterial isolates, one identified as Vibrio cholerae and the other as Escherichia coli. What laboratory test would most reliably differentiate these two organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxidase test.

 

Option A:

 

Vibrio cholerae is oxidase positive, which means it possesses the enzyme cytochrome c oxidase and can convert tetramethyl-p-phenylenediamine to a colored compound. This is a key test to differentiate it from E. coli, which is oxidase negative.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Catalase test - Incorrect, both V. cholerae and E. coli are catalase positive.

 

Option C. Optochin sensitivity - Incorrect, this test is used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci.

 

Option D. Lactose fermenter - Incorrect, while E. coli is a lactose fermenter, this test is not definitive because some strains of V. cholerae can also ferment lactose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxidase test is correct for identifying Vibrio cholerae, as it is oxidase positive, differentiating it from E. coli, which is oxidase negative. V. cholerae and E. coli are catalase positive, making the Catalase test ineffective; the Optochin sensitivity test is for differentiating Streptococcus pneumoniae, not relevant here; and the Lactose fermenter test is not definitive as some V. cholerae strains can ferment lactose.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p334, 2/e p346

questions.text: A medical student is preparing a presentation on the history of cholera pandemics. When discussing the 8th pandemic, they should include all of the following accurate statements except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-Capsulated.

 

Option D:

 

The 8th pandemic of cholera was caused by a new serogroup of Vibrio cholerae, O139 Bengal, which is encapsulated. This pandemic began in 1992 and was first identified in Bangladesh. It spread to India but was not confined to these countries alone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Caused by Vibrio cholerae O139 - Correct, the 8th pandemic was caused by this serogroup.

 

Option B. Started in 1992 - Correct, this is when the 8th pandemic began.

 

Option C. New strain was first identified in Bangladesh - Correct, although new strain was first identified in Bangladesh, it was not confined to only Bangladesh &/or India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the 8th cholera pandemic was caused by Vibrio cholerae O139, which is encapsulated, started in 1992, and was first identified in Bangladesh.

questions.text: A microbiology laboratory technician is tasked with isolating Vibrio species from a stool sample of a patient with suspected cholera. Which of the following culture media should the technician use to selectively isolate Vibrio species?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TCBS.

 

Option A:

 

Thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar is a selective and differential medium designed to isolate Vibrio species, especially Vibrio cholerae. Its high pH (8.6) selects for Vibrio by inhibiting the growth of most enteric bacteria, while the sucrose allows for differentiation based on sucrose fermentation. V. cholerae can ferment sucrose and therefore produce large yellow colonies. This is widely used at present. 

 

 

Figure: TCBS agar with yellow colored colonies of Vibrio cholerae

 

Other Selective Agar’s for Vibrio – 

 

  • Alkaline bile salt agar (BSA): V. cholerae produces translucent oil drop colonies
  • Monsur’s gelatin taurocholate trypticase tellurite agar (GTTTA): V. cholerae produces translucent colonies with a grayish black center and a turbid halo. Classical biotypes grow better on this medium than on TCBS agar
  • MacConkey agar: When not sure about the type of enteric pathogen present in feces, MacConkey agar can be included in the panel. Being a mildly selective medium, it also supports other enteric pathogens such as Shigella and Salmonella. Colonies of V. cholerae are translucent and pale which may become pink on prolonged incubation (due to late lactose fermentation).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Stuart - Incorrect, Stuart's medium is a transport medium, not a selective medium for Vibrio.

 

Option C. Skirrow’s - Incorrect, Skirrow's medium is used for the isolation of Campylobacter.

 

Option D. MYPA - Incorrect, MYPA (mannitol-yeast extract-potassium phosphate agar) is not a selective medium for Vibrio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TCBS agar is the selective medium for the isolation of Vibrio species from clinical specimens.V. cholerae can ferment sucrose and therefore produce large yellow colonies

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p334, 2/e p347, Ananthanarayan 9/e p304, 10/e p315- 316

choices.text: Growth on MacConkey agar without fermentation
A positive D-test for clindamycin resistance

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease presents with fever, confusion, and headache. His wife reports that he has had a decreased appetite and has been less active over the past week. On examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 38.7°C, neck stiffness is noted, and Brudzinski's sign is positive. Blood cultures are drawn, and he is started on empirical antibiotic therapy. The Gram stain of the CSF shows gram-positive rods. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be associated with the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tumbling motility at room temperature

 

Option B:

 

The patient's clinical presentation is suggestive of bacterial meningitis, and the CSF Gram stain showing gram-positive rods points towards Listeria monocytogenes, especially given the patient's advanced age and immunocompromised state. Listeria is characterized by tumbling motility at room temperature due to its flagella, which distinguishes it from other gram-positive rods that could also present in CSF. This feature, combined with the patient's risk factors, makes this the most likely diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Growth on MacConkey agar without fermentation is not characteristic of Listeria, as it does not grow well on this medium.

 

Option C: Urease production is not a feature of Listeria monocytogenes; it is associated with organisms like Proteus species.

 

Option D: A positive D-test for clindamycin resistance is associated with certain strains of staphylococci and streptococci, not Listeria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria should be considered in the differential diagnosis of meningitis in immunocompromised individuals and the elderly. It is characterized by tumbling motility at room temperature, which can be observed under a microscope. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p296

questions.text: A 40-year-old aquarium worker presents with a chronic, non-healing ulcer on the hand that he reports developed after sustaining a minor injury while cleaning a fish tank. A biopsy of the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation. Which mycobacterium species is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium marinum

 

Option B:

 

Mycobacterium marinum is associated with 'fish tank granuloma,' an infection typically acquired from non-chlorinated water or fish tanks. It presents as a granulomatous skin lesion following a penetrating injury from an aquatic environment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium kansasii: Incorrect as it typically causes pulmonary disease resembling tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium paratuberculosis: Incorrect because it is known to cause Johne's disease in cattle, not skin infections in humans.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium gordonae: Incorrect as it is generally considered a non-pathogenic environmental organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium marinum as the causative agent of granulomatous skin infections known as 'fish tank granuloma,' which occurs after direct exposure to non-chlorinated water or fish tanks.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 2/e p295, Ananthanarayan 9/e p360, 10/e p367

choices.text: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for H. pylori

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of epigastric pain. The pain is intermittent, worse at night, and relieved by eating. He has not taken any over-the-counter medications. On endoscopy, he has a duodenal ulcer. Biopsy specimens from the antrum are obtained. Which diagnostic test will most likely confirm the suspected etiology of his ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rapid urease test

 

Option A:

 

The rapid urease test is often performed on a biopsy from the gastric mucosa to detect Helicobacter pylori, the most common cause of duodenal ulcers. This organism produces urease, which hydrolyzes urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide, and can be rapidly identified with this test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The urea breath test is a non-invasive test that can also confirm H. pylori infection but is not performed on biopsy specimens.

 

Option C: Serology for H. pylori can indicate past exposure but does not confirm active infection.

 

Option D: PCR for H. pylori is highly specific but not routinely used due to cost and is not as readily available as the urease test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic test for Helicobacter pylori in a patient with a duodenal ulcer is the rapid urease test performed on gastric biopsy specimen. It is a quick and effective method for diagnosing active H. pylori infection.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p364, 2/e p379

questions.text: In a research lab, a scientist is studying various strains of mycobacteria. She notes that one particular strain does not belong to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex (MTBC) group. Which of the following mycobacteria is not a member of the MTBC?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mycobacterium kansasii

 

Option D:

 

The Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex (MTBC) consists of species that can cause tuberculosis in humans, including M. tuberculosis, M. africanum, and M. bovis. Mycobacterium kansasii, although it can cause tuberculosis-like diseases, is not a member of the MTBC.

 

M. tuberculosis complex includes:

 

  • M. tuberculosis : It is the most common species to cause TB in man
  • M. bovis (bovine tubercle bacillus)
  • Other members are less common human pathogens, such as M. africanum, M. microti, M. caprae, M. pinnipedii, M. canetti, M. suricattae, M. orygis, M. mungi and the recently described dassie bacillus and chimpanzee bacillus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium africanum: Incorrect as it is part of the MTBC and is known to cause tuberculosis in West Africa.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Incorrect because it is the primary causative agent of tuberculosis and is part of the MTBC.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium bovis: Incorrect as it is part of the MTBC and is also known to cause tuberculosis, primarily in cattle but also in humans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium kansasii is not a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex, although it can cause tuberculosis-like diseases. It causes chronic pulmonary disease resembling tuberculosis

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 2/e p281,295, Ananthanarayan 9/e p354,359, 10/e p351

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a chronic skin condition. On examination, several distinctive facial features are noted, which are suggestive of a longstanding mycobacterial infection. Which of the following features is commonly seen in patients with untreated Leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Leonine facies

 

Option D:

 

Leonine facies, characterized by facial thickening due to skin infiltration and nodularity, is a classical feature of lepromatous leprosy. It is associated with the advanced stage of the disease and results from the infiltration of Mycobacterium leprae into the facial skin.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Saddle nose: Incorrect, while this can be seen in leprosy due to destruction of the nasal septum, it is not as characteristic as leonine facies. It is characteristic of congenital syphilis, Untreated early syphilis infections can cause saddle nose deformity,

 

Option B. Small earlobe: Incorrect, as this is not a recognized feature of leprosy.

 

Option C. Ptosis: Incorrect, as ptosis is not typically a feature of leprosy but may occur secondary to facial nerve involvement in some cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic facial feature of leonine facies is a classical feature of lepromatous leprosy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p288, 2/e p299

choices.text: Patients who have received the lepromin test
Patients undergoing multidrug therapy for leprosy

questions.text: A dermatologist is treating a patient with lepromatous leprosy who develops tender erythematous nodules on the skin and complains of systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. This acute inflammatory complication is known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL). Which patient population is most commonly affected by this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patients with lepromatous leprosy (LL)

 

Option C:

 

Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) is an immune complex-mediated complication that occurs predominantly in patients with lepromatous leprosy, the multibacillary form of the disease. It is characterized by painful nodules, systemic symptoms, and can be precipitated by immune system changes during treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patients who have received the lepromin test: Incorrect as ENL is not caused by the lepromin test, which is a skin test used in leprosy.

 

Option B. Patients undergoing multidrug therapy for leprosy: Incorrect as ENL is not directly caused by the therapy but can be a reaction associated with immune changes during treatment.

 

Option D. Patients with tuberculoid leprosy (TT): Incorrect because ENL is much less common in the paucibacillary form of the disease, such as tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) is indeed an immune complex-mediated complication primarily occurring in patients with lepromatous leprosy (LL), which is the multibacillary form of leprosy. ENL is characterized by painful nodules and systemic symptoms and can be triggered by changes in the immune system during treatment.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p288, 2/e p299, Park 23/e p324, 24/e p342

questions.text: A clinician is discussing the long-term management of a patient who has completed treatment for multibacillary leprosy. For how many years should the patient be monitored annually to ensure no relapse occurs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 years

 

Option B:

 

According to WHO guidelines, patients who have completed treatment for multibacillary leprosy should be followed up annually for at least 5 years to monitor for any signs of relapse, as the risk of relapse remains significant for several years post-treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Operational Classification of Leprosy (according to skin smear positivity) to serve as a basis for Chemotherapy

 

 

OAMS: Once a month supervised

1–10 bacilli per 100 oil immersion fields
No bacilli in all fields

questions.text: A laboratory technician is performing a smear test for leprosy and observes bacilli under the microscope. To quantify the bacterial load, the technician refers to the bacteriological index (BI). What does a bacteriological index of 1+ indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1–10 bacilli per 100 oil immersion fields

 

Option B:

 

A bacteriological index (BI) of 1+ indicates a bacterial load of 1–10 bacilli per 100 oil immersion fields on a smear from a leprosy patient. This semi-quantitative scale helps to assess the bacterial burden and the effectiveness of treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. < 100 bacilli per oil immersion field: Incorrect as this does not correspond to the standardized BI scale for 1+.

 

Option C. No bacilli in all fields: Incorrect because the presence of any bacilli indicates a BI greater than zero.

 

Option D. Bacilli in all fields: Incorrect as this would suggest a higher BI than 1+.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial/Bacteriological index (BI): Density of bacilli in smears, including both living and dead bacilli

 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p290, 2/e p300, Park, 24/e p337

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of leprosy comes to the clinic for a follow-up. The physician knows that leprosy can affect multiple organ systems. Which of the following is NOT typically affected by leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ovary

 

Option B:

 

Leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae, can affect multiple organs, including the nerves (leading to neuropathy), eyes (leading to blindness), and testes (leading to infertility). The ovaries, however, are not typically affected by leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Testes: Incorrect as leprosy can affect the testes, causing gynecomastia and infertility.

 

Option C. Eye: Incorrect because leprosy can involve the eye, leading to blindness.

 

Option D. Nerve: Incorrect as nerve involvement is one of the hallmark features of leprosy, leading to numbness and muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leprosy can involve the testes (causing gynecomastia and infertility), eyes (leading to blindness), and nerves (resulting in numbness and muscle weakness). It is essential to note that ovarian involvement is not a common manifestation of leprosy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p288, 2/e p298, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1124, 20/e p1261, Internet source

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with fever, headache, and a rash after a camping trip in an area known for scrub vegetation. He recalls multiple insect bites. A diagnosis of scrub typhus is suspected. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Doxycycline

 

Option D:

 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for scrub typhus, which is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. It is an intracellular bacterium transmitted by the bite of infected chiggers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythromycin: Incorrect because while it can be used in cases where doxycycline is contraindicated (such as in pregnant women or children), doxycycline is the preferred first-line treatment.

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Incorrect as it is primarily used for anaerobic bacterial infections and protozoal infections, not rickettsial diseases like scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Sulfonamides: Incorrect because they are not effective against the organism that causes scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, as it effectively targets the intracellular bacterium transmitted through chigger bites. 

Erythromycin can be an alternative in cases where doxycycline is contraindicated (e.g., pregnant women or children), but it is not the first-line choice. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p408
